Ransomware Tsunami: The Quickest Way to Protect and Recover

One of the biggest cybersecurity threats currently is ransomware. It gets a lot of press and attention, and rightly so.

Ransomware can cripple or push a SMB to bankruptcy within 6 months.

The statistics are staggering.

60% of small companies that suffer a cyber-attack are out of business within six months.

From https://www.denverpost.com/2016/10/23/small-companies-cyber-attack-out-of-business/ 

Roughly 40-60 percent of small businesses never reopen their doors following a disaster

From https://www.fema.gov/media-library/assets/documents/108451

Ransomware shuts down 1 in 5 small businesses after it hits

From https://www.cnet.com/news/malwarebytes-state-of-ransomware-shutting-down-1-in-5-affected-small-businesses/

 

Table of Contents

  • Ransomware Tsunami: The Quickest Way to Protect and Recover
    •  What is Ransomware?
    • How Does Ransomware Work?
    • How is Ransomware Delivered?
    • The Steps to Prepare For Ransomware Attacks
      • Inventory
        • Devices
        • Inventory Digital
        • Data
        • Server and PC / Laptop Contents
      • Backups
        • Best Practices
        • Backup Storage Locations
        • Backup Software
      • Disaster Recovery (DR)
        • Disaster Recovery Planning
          • DR Recovery

 What is Ransomware?

Ransomware is a type of malware installed on a computer or server that encrypts the files, making them inaccessible until a specified ransom is paid. Ransomware is typically installed when a user clicks on a malicious link, opens a file in an e-mail that installs the malware, or through drive-by downloads (which does not require user-initiation) from a compromised Web site.

From https://www.ic3.gov/media/2016/160915.aspx

Ransomware is a type of malware threat actors use to infect computers and encrypt computer files until a ransom is paid. (See Protecting Against Malicious Code for more information on malware.) After the initial infection, ransomware will attempt to spread to connected systems, including shared storage drives and other accessible computers.
If the threat actor’s ransom demands are not met (i.e., if the victim does not pay the ransom), the files or encrypted data will usually remain encrypted and unavailable to the victim. Even after a ransom has been paid to unlock encrypted files, threat actors will sometimes demand additional payments, delete a victim’s data, refuse to decrypt the data, or decline to provide a working decryption key to restore the victim’s access. The Federal Government does not support paying ransomware demands. (See the FBI’s ransomware article.)

From https://www.us-cert.gov/ncas/tips/ST19-001

How Does Ransomware Work?

Ransomware identifies the drives on an infected system and begins to encrypt the files within each drive. Ransomware generally adds an extension to the encrypted files, such as .aaa, .micro, .encrypted, .ttt, .xyz, .zzz, .locky, .crypt, .cryptolocker, .vault, or .petya, to show that the files have been encrypted—the file extension used is unique to the ransomware type.

Once the ransomware has completed file encryption, it creates and displays a file or files containing instructions on how the victim can pay the ransom. If the victim pays the ransom, the threat actor may provide a cryptographic key that the victim can use to unlock the files, making them accessible.

How is Ransomware Delivered?

Ransomware is commonly delivered through phishing emails or via “drive-by downloads.” Phishing emails often appear as though they have been sent from a legitimate organization or someone known to the victim and entice the user to click on a malicious link or open a malicious attachment. A “drive-by download” is a program that is automatically downloaded from the internet without the user’s consent or often without their knowledge. It is possible the malicious code may run after download, without user interaction. After the malicious code has been run, the computer becomes infected with ransomware.

From https://www.us-cert.gov/ncas/tips/ST19-001 

In a ransomware attack, victims—upon seeing an e-mail addressed to them—will open it and may click on an attachment that appears legitimate, like an invoice or an electronic fax, but which actually contains the malicious ransomware code. Or the e-mail might contain a legitimate-looking URL, but when a victim clicks on it, they are directed to a website that infects their computer with malicious software.

Once the infection is present, the malware begins encrypting files and folders on local drives, any attached drives, backup drives, and potentially other computers on the same network that the victim computer is attached to. Users and organizations are generally not aware they have been infected until they can no longer access their data or until they begin to see computer messages advising them of the attack and demands for a ransom payment in exchange for a decryption key. These messages include instructions on how to pay the ransom, usually with bitcoins because of the anonymity this virtual currency provides.

From https://www.fbi.gov/news/stories/incidents-of-ransomware-on-the-rise

The Steps to Prepare For Ransomware Attacks


This list of steps will prepare your SMB to defend against a ransomware attack and help you recover if the attack is successful.

Note: Notice the + sign after some list items

  1. If a list item has a +1, +2, or +3 after it then that means additional levels of complexity and expertise are needed.
  2. If a list item has no +1, +2, or +3 behind it, then it means this is a basic step to better cybersecurity
  3. +1 means a little bit more complex than the basic steps
  4. +2 means fairly advanced over the basic steps
  5. +3 means very advanced over the basic steps

 

Inventory

Create an inventory of all your computer and digital assets, recording the results on the computer, on paper, or both.

Devices

Network Let's talk about the network TODO link

Backups

Backing up data and documents regularly is extreme important. Offline backups is the best way to combat ransomware. Examples of offline backups include storing backups on removeable hard drives, removeable USB hard drives and secure cloud infrastructures with 30 days of restore capabilities.

Best Practices
  1. Verify backups by either using your software backup tool or scripts, verify that the backup integrety is valid
  2. Restore and validate backups to a test computer, test server, or empty drive
  3. Have at least 2-3 locations to where you backup your data and documents
  4. Keep good records where and when the backups were made
  5. For SQL database backups, do a log backup every 30 minutes or so, an diff backup after 4 hours during the work day, and a full backup at night. Adjust the frequency as needed. Then copy or ship the backups to various backup locations.
  6. Compression can help reduce the size of SQL database backups. Experiment with the various settings on a test server.
  7. Encryption can help make the SQL database backups more secure while the data is at "rest". If you have any PII (personally identifying information), PCI, HIPAA or the like, encrypted SQL backups are manditory.

How Pixar’s Toy Story 2 was deleted twice, once by technology and again for its own good

From https://thenextweb.com/media/2012/05/21/how-pixars-toy-story-2-was-deleted-twice-once-by-technology-and-again-for-its-own-good/

Backup Storage Locations
List Item Description
Offline Great option which you can control where the offline backups are stored, and ransomware cannot touch it.
Local Good for quick restores but easily exploited by ransomware. Not a safe choice to avoid ransomware.
Cloud Great option if the cloud vendor can protect your cloud data and restore when you need it. If the cloud vendor has geographically redundant servers spread across the country, even better.
Remote Great option if you can rent, lease, or purchase remote servers in another location. It is best to find a remote location in another time zone or region from you, in case of natural disasters, which could wipe out servers in your region.
Co Locate Great option if you can rent, lease, or purchase co-located remote servers in another location. It is best to find a remote location in another time zone or region from you, in case of natural disasters, which could wipe out servers in your region.
Backup Software

A partial list of backup software. You can use your search engine of preference to find more choices.

32 Free Backup Software Tools

22 Cloud Backup Services Reviewed

Best Exchange Server Monitoring Software & Tools for Monitoring & Managing Exchange Services

I recommend OneDrive for Business (Cloud Backups) for at least your documents backup. The best plan is Office 365 Business Premium.

Benefits

  1. Reasonable price per user
  2. Can help you recover data after a ransomware attack
  3. Can automatically sync data and documents to the cloud
  4. Microsoft technical phone support
  5. Advanced security and compliance capabilities
  6. With the Office 365 Business Premium plan you can host unlimited HD video conferencing meetings for up to 250 people
  7. With the Office 365 Business Premium plan you get 5 licenses for the latest Microsoft Office tools - 5 licenses for PC/laptop, 5 for tablets, and 5 for phones.
  8. With the Office 365 Business Premium plan you get access to cloud versions of Exchange email, SharePoint Intranet, Microsoft Teams, and Yammer.

From https://onedrive.live.com/about/en-us/business/ 

If you run your own email server at your office, I highly recommend moving to Office 365 in the cloud

Benefits

  1. All of your checked in documents and data stored in SharePoint Online are safe from ransomware
  2. SharePoint Online gives you version control over every document
  3. SharePoint Online allows to assign permissions to read and write documents
  4. Exchange Online can filter out most spam, phishing, and suspect emails
  5. No maintenance and patching, Microsoft does all that for you
  6. Advanced security and compliance capabilities
  7. Free up your server for other functions
  8. Backups are done by Microsoft
  9. Cloud gets the latest features first
  10. Administrating Office 365 is pretty simple
  11. Office 365 allows to conduct security audits
  12. You can write PowerShell scripts for Office 365 to automate even more

Disaster Recovery (DR)

Disaster Recovery is key to getting your business back to work quickly after a ransomware attack. Without a plan, chaos and confusion will limit the effectiveness of your response.

Disaster Recovery Planning

 

List Item Description
DR Contacts and Roles Have a list of people to contact and what role will they play
DR Participants Have a list of people that will participate in the DR and what role will they play
DR Assessment Have an experinced IT person determine if ransomware has attacked
DR Recovery See below
DR Simulated Attack Have a list of people that will participate in the DR simulation and what role will they play
DR Recovery

 

List Item Description
Device Maps Creat a map of the Network, PCs, laptops, phones, and other devices
Operating System - O/S Create a boot O/S for each type of O/S
Device Drivers Create a collection of all the device drivers
Hardware Rent or borrow until the recovery is complete, if needed
Software Create a collection of all the O/S media, software media
User Documents Validate that all the critical documents have been backed up to offline or cloud
Database Server Validate that you can flatten a server, install the O/S, install the SQL Server media and tools to the server, and configure the SQL server
Database Server Data  Validate that you can restore all the data from the last backups and also at any point in time
Email Server Validate that you can flatten a server, install the O/S, install the Exchange media and tools to the server, and configure the Exchange server
Email Server Data Validate that you can restore all the data from the last backups and also at any point in time
Web Server Validate that you can flatten a server, install the O/S, install the IIS media and tools to the server, and configure the IIS server
Web Server Data Validate that you can restore all the data from the last backups and also at any point in time
Phones Flatten if needed, reinstall O/S, software

Get Started on Your Cybersecurity SMB Evaluation

This is a great list of ideas to get you started on your cybersecurity journey to mitigate or prevent cyber attacks on your SMB.

Table of Contents

  • Get Started on Your Cybersecurity SMB Evaluation
  • The first step in protecting a business from cyber threats is to identify the “crown jewels” of your business – those assets and systems that are critical to your business.
    • Quick Wins
    • Additional Resources to Put into Action
  • Now that you’ve identified your data and devices, how do you protect them?
    • Quick Wins
    • Additional Resources to Put into Action
  • Detection is all about knowing when something has gone wrong.
    • Quick Wins
    • Additional Resources to Put Into Action
  • Having a recovery plan created before an attack occurs is critical. Make and practice an incident response plan to contain an attack or incident and maintain business operations in the short term.
    • Quick Wins
    • Additional Resources to Put Into Action
  • The goal of recovery is to move from the immediate aftermath of a cyber incident to full restoration of normal systems and operations.
    • Quick Wins
    • Resources to Put Into Action

This is what the National Cyber Security Alliance (NCSA) provides in web pages and videos in about 10 hours of reading and 20 hours of video watching.

The National Cyber Security Alliance’s (NCSA’s) CyberSecure My Business™ is a national program helping small and medium-sized businesses (SMBs) learn to be safer and more secure online. Make cyber secure your new stuff. National Cyber Security Alliance (NCSA) makes great tips.

The program is a series of in-person, highly interactive and easy-to-understand workshops based on the National Institute of Standards and Technology (NIST) Cybersecurity Framework to educate the SMB community about. 

  Click here to Sign up for a Free 2 Hour Online SMB Cybersecurity Review

 

 We instead provide a condensed version of the framework in a series of checklists, tips and suggestions, and cautions of what to avoid.

  • Identifying and understanding which business assets (“digital crown jewels”) others want
  • Learning how to protect those assets
  • Detecting when something has gone wrong
  • Responding quickly to minimize impact and implement an action plan
  • Learning what resources are needed to recover after a breach

Additional components include: monthly webinars with industry, government and nonprofit cybersecurity experts, an online portal of resources to help the SMB community and monthly newsletters summarizing the latest cybersecurity news.

The first step in protecting a business from cyber threats is to identify the “crown jewels” of your business – those assets and systems that are critical to your business.

Crown jewels are the data without which your business would have difficulty operating and/or the information that could be a high-value target for cybercriminals.

Quick Wins

  • Create a detailed inventory list of data and physical assets and update it routinely. Record the manufacturer, make, model, serial number and support information for hardware and software. For software, know the specific version that is installed and running. 
  • Know where data and technology are stored and who has access to both.

We will help you collect a complete inventory of all your software and hardware that is critical to your business continuity.

Then we can help you analyze the risk to each item and determine the remediation action to correct the risk.

  Click here to Sign up for a Free 2 Hour Online SMB Cybersecurity Review

 Additional Resources to Put into Action

U.S. Department of Homeland Security

  • Resources for Business – Identify
  • C3VP SMB Toolkit
  • Cyber Resilience Review

Michigan Small Business Development Center, Small Business-Big Threat

  • Small Business Cybersecurity Awareness Canvass

Insurance Institute for Business and Home Safety

Federal Communications Commission

Georgia Procurement Technical Assistance Center

  • Defense Federal Acquisition Regulation Supplement Cybersecurity Guidance for Government Contractors

Now that you’ve identified your data and devices, how do you protect them?

Ultimately, your goal is to build a culture of cybersecurity that includes employees knowing how to protect themselves and the business and understanding the cyber risks as your business grows or adds new technologies or functions.

Quick Wins

  • Keep security software current: Having the latest security software, web browser and operating system is the best defense against viruses, malware and other online threats.
  • Automate Software Updates: Many software programs will automatically connect and update to defend against known risks. Turn on automatic updates if that’s an available option.

  • Use strong authentication to protect access to accounts and ensure only those with permission can access them. This also includes enforcing strong passphrases.
  • Back up data: Put in place a system – either in the cloud or via separate hard drive storage – that makes electronic copies of the key information on a regular basis.
  • Limit access to data or systems only to the employees who require it to perform the core duties of their jobs.
  • Keep a clean machine: Your company should have clear rules for what employees can install and keep on their work computers.
  • When in doubt, throw it out: Employees should know not to open suspicious links in email, tweets, posts, online ads, messages or attachments – even if they know the source. Employees should also be instructed about your company’s spam filters and how to use them to prevent unwanted, harmful email.

Stay watchful and speak up: Encourage employees to keep an eye out and say something if they notice anything strange on their computer.

Additional Resources to Put into Action

Cofense

  • Cofense PhishMe Free for Sm(all) – Simulated Phishing Application

Federal Inter-Agency Ransomware Guidance

  • How to Protect Your Networks From Ransomware

Federal Trade Commission

  • Protecting Small Businesses Resources

MediaPro

  • Awareness Training Videos

SANS

  • Information Security Policy Templates

TeleSign

  • Learn How to Turn On 2-Factor Authentication

U.S. Department of Homeland Security

  • Cybersecurity While Traveling Tip Card

 

 Click here to Sign up for a Free 2 Hour Online SMB Cybersecurity Review

 

Detection is all about knowing when something has gone wrong.

We have fire alarms in our businesses and homes that alert us to problems. In cybersecurity, the more quickly you know about an incident, the more quickly you can mitigate the impact and get back to normal operations.

Quick Wins

  • Email. Look for unusual requests, attachments, links. Be suspicious.
  • Use cybersecurity products or services that help monitor your networks (think of antivirus and anti-malware software, for example)
  • Physical Security. Are employees/customers acting suspiciously? Are people in locations they shouldn’t be? Do you notice someone not following established policy? Be sure to consider physical security as well.
  • Users. Train employees to know what incidents and attacks look like and that they need to be reported quickly.
  • Talk to others in your industry and reach out to local IT experts about exploring the option of improving your protections using some kind of network monitoring service that helps to detect incidents. The availability of cybersecurity tools and services is growing.

Additional Resources to Put Into Action

Federal Bureau of Investigation Internet Crimes Complaint Center

  • Business Email Compromise: The 5 Billion Dollar Scam

Federal Trade Commission

  • Small Business Scams

National Institute of Standards and Technology

  • Small Business Cybersecurity Fundamentals

Trend Micro 

  • Webinar: Breach Detection Best Practices

Having a recovery plan created before an attack occurs is critical. Make and practice an incident response plan to contain an attack or incident and maintain business operations in the short term.

Even when we take all the precautions we can, incidents can still happen. Being prepared to respond in a thoughtful and comprehensive manner will reduce risks to your business and send a positive signal to your customers and employees.

The good news is, preparing to respond to a cyber incident is in not unlike preparing for other events that could impact your business like natural or manmade disasters. Building your cyber incident response can tap your other operational knowledge and experience.

Quick Wins

  • Disconnect the affected computer(s) from the network and connect with IT leadership (Whether that’s internal to your organization or a third party vendor), law enforcement and your legal representation.
  • Utilize spares and backup while continuing to capture operational data.
  • Switch to paper. Are electronic records unavailable? Have processes for operating by paper to keep the business functioning. You need to understand how you would access some key information if your systems were down.
  • Familiarize yourself with your state’s data breach notification law.

Additional Resources to Put Into Action

AT&T

  • Cyber Breach Response

Federal Bureau of Investigation

  • File a Complaint With the Internet Crime Complaint Center

Federal Communications Commission (FCC)

  • FCC Response Plan Template

Federal Trade Commission (FTC)

  • FTC Complaint Assistant helps you file a complaint, whether you’re reporting identity theft, a scam, unwanted messages, credit and debt issues or another concern.
  • IdentityTheft.gov can help you report and recover from identity theft.
  • Data Breach Response Guide
  • Actions Steps to Take Immediately After a Hack is Identified

National Conference of State Legislatures

  • Security Breach Notification Laws

U.S. Department of Homeland Security

  • Resources for Business – RESPOND
  • Guide to Cyber Incident Reporting: A Unified Message for Reporting to the Federal Government

 

Click here to Sign up for a Free 2 Hour Online SMB Cybersecurity Review

 

The goal of recovery is to move from the immediate aftermath of a cyber incident to full restoration of normal systems and operations.

The final step of making your business more cybersecure includes the recovery efforts after responding to a cyber incident. Like the response step, recovery requires planning. Recovery is not just about fixing the causes and preventing the recurrence of a single incident. It’s about building out your cybersecurity posture across the whole organization (not just the IT person or group), including increasing the focus on planning for future events.

Quick Wins

  • Document lessons learned.
  • Make improvements to policies & procedures and communicate that to all parties.
  • Establish continuing education opportunities–train your employees and yourself.
  • Take steps to repair reputation, which might require you to engage with a PR firm. Decide who is responsible for communicating with external stakeholders and what the message will be

 Resources to Put Into Action

National Institute for Standards and Technology

  • Guide for Cybersecurity Incident Recovery

Ready.gov

  • IT Disaster Recovery Plan

U.S. Department of Homeland Security

  • Cyber Risk Insurance Overview
  • Resources for Business – RECOVER
